faqs.question: How much paint do I need for a 12x12 room?
faqs.answer: A 12x12 room with 8-foot ceilings has about 384 sq ft of wall area. After deducting doors and windows, 2 gallons covers 2 coats.

faqs.question: How many square feet does a gallon of paint cover?
faqs.answer: One gallon covers 350-400 sq ft on smooth surfaces for one coat. Textured surfaces may only get 250-300 sq ft per gallon.

faqs.question: Do I need primer before painting?
faqs.answer: Primer is recommended for new drywall, dramatic color changes, stain blocking, and adhesion on glossy surfaces. Many paints now include primer.

faqs.question: How many coats of paint do I need?
faqs.answer: Two coats is standard for most applications. One coat may suffice when repainting the same color; three coats for dramatic color changes.

faqs.question: What is the difference between interior and exterior paint?
faqs.answer: Exterior paint contains additives for UV resistance, mildew prevention, and temperature flexibility. Interior paint focuses on washability and low odor.

faqs.question: How many tiles do I need per square foot?
faqs.answer: For 12x12 inch tiles: 1 tile per sq ft. For 6x6 inch tiles: 4 per sq ft. For 18x18 inch tiles: 0.44 per sq ft. Add 10% for waste.

faqs.question: How much extra tile should I order?
faqs.answer: Order 10% extra for standard layouts, 15% for diagonal or herringbone patterns, and 20% for complex patterns or rooms with many cuts.

faqs.question: What size grout lines should I use?
faqs.answer: Standard is 1/8 inch (3mm). Use 1/16 inch for rectified tiles, 1/4 inch or more for rustic or hand-made tiles.

faqs.question: Can I use floor tiles on walls?
faqs.answer: Yes, but wall tiles cannot go on floors. Floor tiles are denser and harder. Check tile ratings for appropriate applications.

faqs.question: How many tiles come in a box?
faqs.answer: This varies by size: 12x12 inch tiles typically 10-12 per box, 6x6 inch tiles 40+ per box. Check manufacturer specifications.

faqs.question: How much grout do I need per square foot?
faqs.answer: Approximately 0.5-1 lb per square foot for 12x12 tiles with 1/8 inch joints. Smaller tiles and wider joints require more grout.

faqs.question: What is the difference between sanded and unsanded grout?
faqs.answer: Sanded grout contains sand for strength in joints over 1/8 inch. Unsanded is smoother for narrow joints and polished tiles that scratch easily.

faqs.question: How long does grout take to dry?
faqs.answer: Grout is walkable in 24 hours but takes 28 days to fully cure. Seal after 72 hours. Avoid heavy traffic for first week.

faqs.question: Do I need to seal grout?
faqs.answer: Yes, cement-based grout should be sealed to prevent staining and moisture absorption. Epoxy grout does not require sealing.

faqs.question: How long does a bag of grout last?
faqs.answer: A 25 lb bag covers approximately 50-200 sq ft depending on tile size and joint width. Smaller tiles with wider joints use more grout.

faqs.question: How many rolls of wallpaper for a 12×12 room?
faqs.answer: A 12×12 room with 8-foot ceilings has approximately 384 sq ft of wall area. After deducting openings, expect 5-7 double rolls depending on pattern repeat.

faqs.question: What is pattern repeat and why does it matter?
faqs.answer: Pattern repeat is the distance before the design repeats. Larger repeats create more waste as strips must be aligned, potentially requiring 20-30% more material.

faqs.question: What is the difference between single and double rolls?
faqs.answer: Single rolls are 27 sq ft, double rolls are 54 sq ft. Most wallpaper is now sold only in double rolls but priced per single roll.

faqs.question: How long does wallpaper last?
faqs.answer: Quality wallpaper lasts 10-15 years or more. Vinyl and washable types are most durable for high-traffic and humid areas.

faqs.question: Can I hang wallpaper over existing wallpaper?
faqs.answer: Not recommended. Remove old wallpaper, repair walls, and apply primer for best adhesion and smooth finish.

faqs.question: How do I calculate wall area for a room?
faqs.answer: Measure the perimeter (sum of wall lengths) and multiply by ceiling height. Subtract door and window areas from the total.

faqs.question: What is the average window size for calculations?
faqs.answer: Standard windows average 3×4 feet (12 sq ft). Measure actual windows for accuracy or use 15-20 sq ft for larger windows.

faqs.question: Should I deduct baseboards and crown molding?
faqs.answer: No, these are typically included in wall area. Only deduct actual openings like doors and windows.

faqs.question: How much area does a gallon of paint cover?
faqs.answer: One gallon covers 350-400 sq ft per coat on smooth walls. Use net wall area after deducting openings.

faqs.question: What is the formula for wall perimeter?
faqs.answer: Add all wall lengths together. For a rectangular room: Perimeter = 2 × (Length + Width).

faqs.question: How many drywall sheets for a 12×12 room?
faqs.answer: A 12×12 room with 8-foot ceilings has 384 sq ft of wall area. Using 4×8 sheets (32 sq ft each), you need approximately 12-14 sheets plus waste.

faqs.question: How many screws per sheet of drywall?
faqs.answer: Plan for 28-32 screws per 4×8 sheet. Screws should be placed every 12 inches on ceilings and 16 inches on walls.

faqs.question: What thickness drywall should I use?
faqs.answer: Use 1/2-inch for most walls, 5/8-inch for ceilings and fire-rated walls. Use 1/4-inch for curved surfaces.

faqs.question: How much joint compound per sheet?
faqs.answer: Plan for approximately 0.5 gallons of joint compound per 4×8 sheet for complete finishing including three coats.

faqs.question: Can I hang drywall vertically?
faqs.answer: Yes, but horizontal installation is preferred for walls as it creates fewer and shorter joints to tape.

faqs.question: How much joint compound per square foot?
faqs.answer: Plan for 0.005-0.01 gallons per sq ft for complete three-coat system. One gallon covers 100-200 sq ft depending on application.

faqs.question: What is the difference between setting and drying compound?
faqs.answer: Setting compound hardens through chemical reaction (20-90 minutes). Drying compound air-dries (24+ hours). Setting is stronger for taping.

faqs.question: Can I add water to joint compound?
faqs.answer: Yes, add small amounts to achieve desired consistency. Thin for skim coating, thicker for filling. Don't over-thin.

faqs.question: How long between coats of joint compound?
faqs.answer: Wait until completely dry - typically 24 hours for drying compound, or follow setting compound instructions (45-90 minutes).

faqs.question: What grit sandpaper for joint compound?
faqs.answer: Use 120 grit between coats, 150-220 grit for final sanding. Use sanding screen or sponge to avoid gouges.

faqs.answer: Minimum 7.5 ft finished ceiling height is typical for residential, 8-9 ft for commercial. Allow 3-6 inches for grid and clearance.

faqs.question: How far apart are main runners?
faqs.answer: Main runners are spaced 4 feet apart for standard installations. Cross tees connect at 2-foot intervals.

faqs.question: Can I install recessed lights in drop ceilings?

faqs.question: What type of ceiling tile is best for bathrooms?

faqs.question: Can I install new flooring over old flooring?

faqs.question: What direction should I lay flooring?

useCases.title: Repair and Replacement
useCases.description: Determine quantities for partial siding repair and storm damage restoration.

seoTips: Always include 10-15% waste factor for cutting around windows and corners
Choose siding material based on climate - fiber cement for humid areas, vinyl for moderate climates
Install proper house wrap and moisture barriers before siding for longevity
Consider color fade warranties - premium vinyl offers 25+ year color protection
Plan for J-channel, corner posts, and trim pieces in your material order

commonMistakes.solution: Include J-channel, corner posts, starter strips, and utility trim in calculations
Use 15% waste for homes with many windows and complex architecture
Always install house wrap before siding to prevent moisture damage
Nail loosely to allow for thermal expansion - siding should move slightly

faqs.question: How many squares of siding do I need?
faqs.answer: One square equals 100 square feet. Divide your wall area by 100 and add 10-15% for waste to determine squares needed.

faqs.question: What is the most durable siding material?
faqs.answer: Fiber cement (HardiePlank) is extremely durable, lasting 50+ years. It resists fire, termites, and rot but is heavier and more expensive than vinyl.

faqs.question: How long does vinyl siding last?
faqs.answer: Quality vinyl siding lasts 20-40 years with minimal maintenance. Premium brands offer lifetime warranties.

faqs.question: Can I install siding over existing siding?
faqs.answer: Yes, in some cases. However, it's better to remove old siding to inspect sheathing, add insulation, and ensure a flat surface.

faqs.question: What is the R-value of insulated siding?
faqs.answer: Insulated vinyl siding adds R-2 to R-5 to your wall assembly, improving energy efficiency by 10-15%.

waterproofing.title: Waterproofing Calculator
waterproofing.description: Calculate waterproofing membrane and coating quantities for moisture protection.
waterproofing.unit_tooltip: Select meters or feet for surface dimensions
waterproofing.formula: Quantity = Area × Coverage Rate × Coats × (1 + Waste). Coverage varies by product type.
waterproofing.info_description: Waterproofing protects structures from moisture damage. Different applications require different products and coverage rates.

errors.positive_values: Area must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_waste: Waste factor must be between 0 and 100

howItWorks.title: How the Waterproofing Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Material = Area × Coats / Coverage Rate × (1 + Waste)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates waterproofing material quantities based on surface area, application type, and number of coats. It includes fabric tape and primer for complete installation.
steps: Enter total surface area to be waterproofed
Select waterproofing application type
Specify number of coats (typically 2)
Set waste factor for overlaps
Review material and accessory quantities

seoTips: Apply two coats minimum for all waterproofing membranes
Use fabric tape at all joints, corners, and penetrations
Extend waterproofing 3-4 inches above expected water level
Allow proper cure time between coats (typically 2-4 hours)
Test waterproofing with flood test before tiling

commonMistakes.solution: Always apply minimum two coats for complete waterproofing
Reinforce all corners and joints with fabric tape embedded in membrane
Allow complete cure between coats - typically 2-4 hours
Flood test shower pans for 24 hours before tiling

faqs.question: How much waterproofing membrane per square foot?
faqs.answer: Liquid membranes cover approximately 50-75 sq ft per gallon per coat. Two coats require double the material.

faqs.question: How long does waterproofing take to dry?
faqs.answer: Most liquid membranes dry to touch in 1-2 hours and cure for recoating in 2-4 hours. Full cure before tiling is 24 hours.

faqs.question: Do I need primer before waterproofing?
faqs.answer: Primer is recommended for porous surfaces like concrete and cement board. Check manufacturer specifications for your substrate.

faqs.question: Can I use waterproofing behind tile?
faqs.answer: Yes, waterproofing membrane behind tile is essential in showers, tub surrounds, and other wet areas to prevent water damage.

faqs.question: What is the difference between vapor barrier and waterproofing?
faqs.answer: Vapor barriers block moisture vapor; waterproofing prevents liquid water penetration. Showers need waterproofing, walls may need vapor barriers.
